'''Dr David Baker''' (born 1944) is a British space scientist and a prolific author. He first visited the USA in 1962<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.skyatnightmagazine.com/news/interview-former-nasa-scientist-david-baker|title=Interview: former NASA scientist David Baker {{!}} BBC Sky at Night Magazine|website=www.skyatnightmagazine.com|access-date=2019-01-15}}</ref> and returned to work for [[NASA]] on the Gemini, Apollo and Space Shuttle programs between 1965 and 1984<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.wired.com/2011/04/human-spaceflight-david-baker/|title=Human Spaceflight's 50th: The Glorious Past and Uncertain Future|last=Grossman|first=Lisa|date=2011-04-12|work=Wired|access-date=2019-01-15|issn=1059-1028}}</ref> as a Mission Planning and Analysis Department. He was present at NASA during [[Apollo 13]] in 1970.

He returned to the UK in 1984 and set up an independent consultancy helping countries around the world including India to develop and integrate commercial space technologies for their national space programmes.

He now works as a journalist, writer and an author. He has published thousands of articles, more than 100 books and contributed to many radio and TV [[imdbname:2894897|documentaries]]  about space missions in the US and Europe. In the past, he has edited the Aerospace Review, Jane's Aircraft Upgrades and Jane's Space Directory. He is a fellow of the [[British Interplanetary Society]] and since 2011 he has been the editor of the BIS's journal - [[Spaceflight (magazine)|Spaceflight]].

'''Daniel Vincent Gordh''' (born 24 June 1985) is an [[United States|American]] actor, writer and comedian, probably best known for his portrayal of [[Mr. Darcy|William Darcy]] in the [[Primetime Emmy Award]]-winning web series ''[[The Lizzie Bennet Diaries]]''.<ref>{{cite web|title=Interview: Daniel Vincent Gordh on 'The Lizzie Bennet Diaries'|url=http://www.hypable.com/interview-lizzie-bennet-diaries-daniel-vincent-gordh-part-1/3/|website=Hypable|accessdate=31 December 2016|date=25 March 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=We Shine the Spotlight on THE LIZZIE BENNET DIARIES Star Daniel Vincent Gordh|url=http://www.thetvaddict.com/2013/04/14/we-shine-the-spotlight-on-the-lizzie-bennet-diaries-star-daniel-vincent-gordh/|website=thetvaddict.com|accessdate=31 December 2016}}</ref>

Gordh completed a [[Bachelor of Arts]] degree in [[Theatre]] at the [[University of California, San Diego]] in 2007.<ref name=lacasting>{{cite web|url=http://www.lacasting.com/resume/resumeprint.asp?rs=1&crypt=diagnimephhohdjjcljpdkmalimnpmkcfcakkkclfdlllnff|title=Resume: Daniel Vincent Gordh|author=LA Casting}}</ref> During college, he competed in springboard diving, and was the [[UCSD]] Diver of the Year for 2006-07.<ref name=lacasting /> Gordh is openly gay, after coming out on social media in 2015.<ref name=stoll>{{cite news|url=http://whatstrending.com/news/21716-the-case-for-hillary-clinton-daniel-v-gordh-katy |work=What’s Trending|title=Interview: The Case for Hillary Clinton|date=March 31, 2016|first=Katy|last=Stoll}}</ref>

Gordh has acted in numerous web series. He was a series regular in ''[[The Lizzie Bennet Diaries]]'' (2012–14), for which he was nominated for the [[Streamy Award]] for Best Actor in a Drama in 2014.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.streamys.org/nominees-winners/4th-annual-nominees-winners/|title=4th Annual Winners & Nominees {{!}} The Streamy Awards|language=en-US|access-date=2016-08-04}}</ref> He also appeared in ''The Cracked Advice Board'' (2011), ''[[Hipsterhood]]'' (2013), ''The Dark Knight Legacy'' (2013) for [[Machinima, Inc.|Machinima]], and ''Hollywood Acting Studio'' (2013), made for the [[Starz]] network.<ref>{{cite web|title=Hollywood Acting Studio: Star Daniel Vincent Gordh Previews His New Outrageous Comedy Web Series|url=http://www.thetvaddict.com/2013/11/25/hollywood-acting-studio-star-daniel-vincent-gordh-previews-his-new-outrageous-comedy-web-series/|website=www.thetvaddict.com|accessdate=31 December 2016}}</ref> 
	
Gordh's television roles include guest appearances on ''[[Cold Case]]'' and ''[[Mad Men]]'', and his film roles include ''Night Watcher'' (2008), ''Black Velvet'' (2011), ''Unfinished Business'' (2015), and ''Non-Transferable'' (2017).<ref name=lacasting />

The waterfall is located in a deep and narrow rock canyon in [[Kazakhstan]], 400 meters from the main gorge. The canyon has a narrow possibility that it is necessary to move along the riverbed. A stream of water escapes from the rock wall at a height of about 20 meters. In terms of its height, water consumption and power, the Big [[Shymbulak]] waterfall is comparable to the [[Medvezhy]] waterfall in the [https://tourstokazakhstan.com/en/sights/almaty-region/turgen-gorge.html Turgen gorge]. Heavy spring precipitation also helps to increase the power of the waterfall, compared with the summer or autumn period, it is not easy to get close to the waterfall, in a few seconds you get soaked to the skin, and all this thanks to water dust. But if you cross the river, then there is not a large observation deck on the hill, where it is relatively dry. Flowing down, the water dug a deep bath at the bottom of the gorge, up to 2 meters deep. The water in this reservoir is very cold even on the hottest day, as it has a glacial origin. Spruce forests in the gorge are absent throughout its entire length. In the lower belt grows apricot and shrubs, barberry, rose hips, and other Shrubs are very prickly. For multi-day hikes, this is a big minus — the lack of firewood. Shrub vegetation is present on the slopes up to the heights of 2200–2400 m of the confluence with the [[Maybulak]] river.

In the extreme Western part of the [[Trans-Ili Alatau]] mountains, which are part of the Northern [[Tian Shan]] mountain system, the ridge sharply degrades and its height decreases (Kastek gorges). Factory gorge is located 50 km West of [[Almaty]]. At the beginning of the gorge is the village of Fabrichny (Kargaly). In order to get to the waterfall you need to go through the village to the water supply zone and then start walking part of the trekking 8 km long

==Protection of objects and visit period==
The object is not protected by anyone and the gorge is not included in the state national Park. The acoustic environment of the object has a favorable climate (silence, melodic sounds in nature). Recommended visiting periods: April–June; August–October. Viewing the waterfall is spectacular at any time of the day, including at night. Mobile communication is difficult. The territory of the monument has no tourist infrastructure, there is no system of tourist signs, food points, and observation platforms are not equipped.

'''Diarmid Heidenreich''' (born 1975) is an Australian film and television actor. Heidenreich graduated from [[Waverley College]] in Sydney's east, in 1993 before going on to become a well-known actor.

==Television career==
Heidenreich began his television career in 1993, appearing in ''[[G. P.]]'' as a guest role. Over the next few years, he had guest roles in several drama series, including ''[[Echo Point (TV series)|Echo Point]]'' (1995) and ''[[Big Sky (TV series)|Big Sky]]'' (1997). Heidenreich was also the host of the children's game show ''Challenger'' until he left the show and Adrian de Vito & Zoe Sheridan co-hosted the show together.

From 1993 to 1996 and again since 2019, Heidenreich starred in a series of television commercials for [[Pizza Hut]], as 'Dougie the Pizza Delivery Guy', which he still is commonly known as. Heidenreich had a leading role in ''[[Water Rats (TV series)|Water Rats]]'' in 2000 and 2001 as Senior Constable Matthew Quinn. In 2003, he had a 4 episode guest role in ''[[McLeod's Daughters]]''. His most recent appearance has been in the Carlton Draught 'Slo Motion' ads.

In 2009, Heidenreich starred in ''[[The Cut (Australian TV series)|The Cut]]'', and had a guest role in ''[[Packed to the Rafters]]''. In 2010 he starred in the TV crime drama ''[[Underbelly: The Golden Mile]]''.<ref>{{cite web|title=Interview: Dieter Brummer & Diarmid Heidenreich (Underbelly)|url=http://www.alicetynan.com/2010/07/interview-dieter-brummer-diarmid.html|website=www.alicetynan.com|accessdate=17 September 2016}}</ref>

In 2015, he guest-starred in ''[[Home and Away]]'', as inmate [[Trevor Gunson]], nemesis of fellow prisoner [[Darryl Braxton]].

==Personal life==
Heidenreich was arrested and served [[periodic detention]] for an incident involving a car crash and drug use, leaving his girlfriend in hospital in 1996.<ref>{{cite news|last=Devlyn|first=Darren|title=Dougie the Pizza boy comes long way|url=http://www.heraldsun.com.au/entertainment/tv-radio/dougie-the-pizza-boy-comes-long-way-as-diarmid-heidenreich-prepares-for-underbelly-role/story-e6frf9ho-1225850813951|newspaper=[[Herald Sun]]|date=7 April 2010}}</ref>

'''Frank Harrison Gassaway''' was a noted American humorist and poet who often wrote under the pseudonym '''Derrick Dodd'''.  Dodd is perhaps most well known for his travel letters ''Summer Saunterings'' published under this pseudonym.  Although little is known of his personal life before he became a prominent writer in California, save that he was of a Virginian family,<ref>Brian Howard: Portrait of a Failure, Marie-Jaqueline Lancaster, Timewell Press, 2005, pg 6</ref> Dodd apparently married a southern belle from Washington D.C. named Elizabeth Paschal and fathered a son, Francis, in 1874 or 1875. Dodd's grandson was the writer [[Brian Howard (poet)|Brian Howard]].<ref>Brian Howard: Portrait of a Failure, Marie-Jaqueline Lancaster, Timewell Press, 2005, pg 6</ref> In 1880, Dodd left Washington D.C. and moved to Oakland, California where he began writing for major San Francisco papers including the ''[[San Francisco Examiner]], [[San Francisco Chronicle|Chronicle]]'' and the ''Evening Post''.  By 1892, Dodd had become the business manager for [[William Randolph Hearst]]'s paper the ''San Francisco Examiner'' and a great admirer of the leading newspaper mogul.  A volume of his poems entitled ''Poems'' was published in 1920 and was dedicated to Hearst.<ref>Green, Martin. ''Children of the Sun''. New York: Basic Books, Inc., Publishers, 1976.</ref>

== Writing career ==
Dodd contributed a humorous column to the ''Evening Post'' and gained notoriety for his Mark Twain-like style and wit.  Some of his writings from this column were compiled in 1882 as the volume ''Summer Saunterings''.  This collection of short travel narratives comments on popular hotels, landmarks and transportation routes in various California cities such as Santa Barbara, Monterey, Napa and San Jose.<ref>[http://memory.loc.gov/cgi-bin/query/h?ammem/calbkbib:@field(NUMBER+@od1(calbk+201)) Library of Congress Digital Collection]</ref>  In his later work, Dodd adopted a more serious and sentimental style, mainly writing poetry dealing with the Civil War.  His most renowned poem, \The Pride of Battery B\" was originally published in the ''San Francisco Examiner''.  This poem

column6: was critically acclaimed and became a popular piece for recitations.  A compilation of Dodd's poetry was published as the volume ''Poems'' in 1920.<ref>Gassaway

'''Dimitrie D. Pătrășcanu''' (October 8, 1872–November 4, 1937) was a [[Romania]]n prose writer and dramatist.

Born in [[Tomești, Iași|Tomești]], [[Iași County]], his parents were Dimitrie Pătrășcanu, a farmer, and his wife Maria (''née'' Vicol). He attended primary school in his native village and in [[Iași]], followed by the [[National College (Iași)|National College]] in the latter city. In 1893, he entered the literature and philosophy faculty of [[Iași University]], as well as the higher normal school. After graduating, he taught history at [[Focșani]], [[Bacău]] and [[Bucharest]]. He authored numerous textbooks, a pursuit to which he dedicated himself entirely in his last years. A member of the [[National Liberal Party (Romania, 1875)|National Liberal Party]], he was elected to the [[Chamber of Deputies (Romania)|Assembly of Deputies]] on a number of occasions.<ref name=\sasu\"/>

column4: '''Bernie Sanders''' is a term used mostly in [[Socialism|socialist]] discourse to refer to a member of the [[proletariat|proletarian]] class who works directly or indirectly against their class interest, or what is against their economic benefit as opposed to that of the [[bourgeoisie]]. It applies particularly to [[soldier]]s, [[police officer]]s, [[bounty hunter]]s, [[loss prevention]], [[Strikebreaker|workers]] who refuse to respect [[Picketing|picket lines]] during a [[Strike action|strike]] and anyone [[Wage labour|paid a wage]] who actively facilitates the ''[[status quo]]''. According to [[Barbara Ehrenreich]]: \Class treason is an option at all socioeconomic levels: from the blue-collar man who becomes a security guard employed to harass striking workers
column5: to the heirs of capitalist fortunes who become donors to left-wing causes\".<ref>{{cite book|author=Ehrenreich
column6: Barbara|title=Fear of Falling: The Inner Life of the Middle Class|url=https://archive.org/details/fearoffalling00barb|url-access=registration|year=1989|pages=[https://archive.org/details/fearoffalling00barb/page/154 154]}}</ref>

column1: In Russia before and during the [[Russian Revolution]]
column2: the [[Bolsheviks]] and other socialist revolutionary organizations used it to describe the [[White movement|Czarist Army]] and any working class citizen who directly opposed their notion of the \"[[dictatorship of the proletariat]]\". The term was later extended to include the [[Menshevik|Menshevik Russians]] and other supposedly [[counter-revolutionary]] socialist organizations under [[Joseph Stalin]].

column1: The motives behind becoming a traitor to one's class can include the necessity of survival (taking up whatever wage is available)
column2: the belief that the person is of a higher class and so has political views that work against the working class
column4: or a rejection of the view that society is divided up into antagonistic classes.

column1: While the idea of the class traitor is one typically applied to the proletariat
column2: it can also be used to describe members of the upper-class who believe in and espouse socialist ideals. For example
column4: an [[Anarcho-communism|anarcho-communist]] who wrote ''[[The Conquest of Bread]]

'''Class traitor''' is a term used mostly in [[Socialism|socialist]] discourse to refer to a member of the [[proletariat|proletarian]] class who works directly or indirectly against their class interest, or what is against their economic benefit as opposed to that of the [[bourgeoisie]]. It applies particularly to [[soldier]]s, [[police officer]]s, [[bounty hunter]]s, [[loss prevention]], [[Strikebreaker|workers]] who refuse to respect [[Picketing|picket lines]] during a [[Strike action|strike]] and anyone [[Wage labour|paid a wage]] who actively facilitates the ''[[status quo]]''. ''The Diver'' is constructed from (approx.) 300 m of galvanised steel banding and 3000 nuts and bolts and weighs 3 tons.  It is secured {{convert|26|ft|m}} into the Thames mud.
John Kaufman (1941–2002) was a self-taught sculptor living and working in the [[London Borough of Havering]]
column2: East London. Inspired by prominent public artist Don Rankin to create his own piece of public art
column3: John embarked on the Diver project in 1995. Initially he financed the project himself but later received funding from [[Veolia|Cleanaway]]
column4: a local refuse company. Receiving mentoring from Don Rankin
column5: support from the Havering London Borough Council in the person of Adam Nardell and additional financial support from friend
column7: John was able to complete and site the statue in August 2000 in its current location. It was installed at 3:30 am in order to avoid river traffic.

column1: The piece is inspired by Kaufman's own family history. His grandfather Friederich Johann Andreas Kaufmann was a diver in the [[London Docks]]<ref name=\"pmsa\">[http://pmsa.cch.kcl.ac.uk/UEL/HA006.htm Public Monument and Sculpture Association] – National Recording Project</ref> c. 1900. The sculpture stands as a monument to this man and all working men of the area who have worked in difficult and dangerous conditions.
Soon after the completion of the sculpture
column2: John fell ill and died in 2002. After his death
column3: a wake was held at the location of the sculpture with family and friends.

column1: The sculpture is sited in the River Thames in Rainham
column2: East London. It can be reached from the Ferry Lane Industrial area and Coldharbour Lane. The car park is found by passing the Tilda rice warehouse.

'''Stephen King''' is a former [[Gaelic football]]er for [[Cavan GAA|Cavan]].<ref>[http://www.gaainfo.com/players/football/cavan/S%20King.php GAA Info] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110711062730/http://www.gaainfo.com/players/football/cavan/S%20King.php |date=2011-07-11 }}</ref>

==Playing career==
He debuted for Cavan in 1980, but did not have much success in the early years, winning only a [[Interprovincial Championship|Railway Cup]] Medal with Ulster in 1984. In 1989, Cavan had a great run in the [[National Football League (Ireland)|National Football League]], claiming the Div. 2 title and reaching the semi final, only to lose narrowly to Dublin in Croke Park. In the same year he won a [[Dr. McKenna Cup]] medal when Cavan defeated Derry in the Final.  He was a member of the Cavan squad that lost out in the Ulster Finals in 1983 and 1996, but in [[1997 Ulster Senior Football Championship Final|1997]], King captained Cavan to claim their only [[Ulster Senior Football Championship]] title in 28 years, beating Derry in Clones.<ref>http://irishnews125.blogspot.com/2009/02/125-cavan-player-list.html</ref><ref>[http://www.hoganstand.com/Cavan/ArticleForm.aspx?ID=78958 hoganstand.com] King of Breffni</ref><ref>[http://www.independent.ie/sport/gaelic-football/former-hero-king-believes-carrs-cavan-heading-in-right-direction-1793385.html independent.ie] former hero king believes carrs cavan heading in right direction</ref><ref>[http://www.independent.ie/sport/cavan-hero-king-retires-454993.html independent.ie] King Retires</ref>

==International rules==
He played for [[Ireland international rules football team|Ireland]] in the [[1987 International Rules series]] against [[Australian International Rules Team|Australia]].<ref>[http://internationalrules.gaa.ie/1987.html International Rules - Series 2 - 1986 – Australia] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090912121923/http://internationalrules.gaa.ie/1987.html |date=2009-09-12 }}</ref>

'''David Boyd Haycock''' (born 1968 in [[Banbury]], [[Oxfordshire]])<ref>{{cite web|title=About me|url=http://www.davidboydhaycock.co.uk/about_me/index.php|publisher=David Boyd Haycock|accessdate=31 March 2011|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110716182405/http://www.davidboydhaycock.co.uk/about_me/index.php|archive-date=16 July 2011|url-status=dead}}</ref> is a British writer, curator and lecturer. He read 'Modern History' at [[St John's College, Oxford]], and has an MA in the History of Art from the University of Sussex and a PhD in History from [[Birkbeck College, London]]. He is the author of a number of books, including ''William Stukeley: Science, Archaeology and Religion in Eighteenth Century England'' (2002) ''Paul Nash'' (2002, 2nd edition 2016),<ref>{{cite book|last=Haycock|first=David Boyd|title=Paul Nash|year=2002|publisher=[[Tate Publishing Ltd|Tate Publishing]]|isbn=1-85437-436-2|oclc=50176269}}</ref> ''Mortal Coil: A Short History of Living Longer'' (2008)<ref>{{cite news|last=Purves|first=Libby|authorlink=Libby Purves|title=Mortal Coil by David Boyd Haycock and Not Dead Yet by Julia Neuberger|url=http://entertainment.timesonline.co.uk/tol/arts_and_entertainment/books/non-fiction/article4079548.ece|work=[[Times Online]]|date=6 June 2008|accessdate=21 February 2011}}</ref> and ''A Crisis of Brilliance: Five Young British Artists and the Great War'' (2009), a group biography of the artists [[Paul Nash (artist)|Paul Nash]], [[Stanley Spencer]], [[Mark Gertler (artist)|Mark Gertler]], [[Dora Carrington]] and [[C.R.W. Nevinson]], all of whom were students together at the [[Slade School of Art]] in London.<ref>{{cite news|last=Uglow|first=Jenny|authorlink=Jenny Uglow|title=A Crisis of Brilliance: Five Young British Artists and the Great War by David Boyd Haycock|url=https://www.theguardian.com/books/2009/nov/21/brilliance-artists-david-haycock-review|work=[[The Guardian]]|date=21 November 2009|accessdate=21 February 2011}}</ref> He lives in Oxford.<ref name=oxfordtimes/>

''A Crisis of Brilliance'' was nominated in the \Best Non-Fiction Book\" category at the 2010 [[Writers' Guild of Great Britain]] awards.<ref name=oxfordtimes>{{cite news|last=Hartford|first=Maggie|title=Double delight for author David|url=http://www.oxfordtimes.co.uk/news/8470974.Double_delight_for_author_David/|work=[[Oxford Times]]|date=23 October 2010|accessdate=21 February 2011}}</ref> An exhibition based on the book was held at [[Dulwich Picture Gallery]] in the summer of 2013. His most recent book was ''I Am Spain: The Spanish Civil War and the Men and Women who went to Fight Fascism'' (2012).

'''Taman Mount Austin''', also known as Austin Heights, is a [[residential area]] in [[Johor Bahru]], [[Johor]], [[Malaysia]]. The neighborhood has a mix of various properties, from terrace homes, semi-detached homes, service apartments, industrial buildings to shop-office lots. It is one of the famous towns in Johor Bahru area, well known for having many restaurants and over 30 [[bubble tea]] shops. It is located in between [[Taman Setia Indah]] and [[Taman Daya]].

'''Paultons Square''' is a Georgian terraced [[garden square]] in [[Chelsea, London|Chelsea]], London, [[SW postcode area|SW3]]. It was built in 1836–40 on the site of a former [[market garden]], land previously owned by [[Sir Thomas More]] and [[Sir John Danvers]].<ref>[http://www.opensquares.org/detail/Paultons.html Paultons Square.]</ref> The square features a central lawn enclosed by metal railings; the houses surrounding it are listed [[Listed building|Grade II]] on the [[National Heritage List for England]].<ref name=NHLE126>{{NHLE|num=1357475|desc=1–26, PAULTONS SQUARE SW3, CHELSEA|access-date=24 October 2016|mode=cs2}}</ref><ref name=NHLE2733>{{NHLE|num=1065900|desc=27–33, PAULTONS SQUARE SW3|access-date=24 October 2016|mode=cs2}}</ref><ref name=NHLE3456>{{NHLE|num=1357476|desc=34–56, PAULTONS SQUARE SW3, CHELSEA|access-date=24 October 2016|mode=cs2}}</ref>

The author [[Gavin Maxwell]] is a notable former resident of the square – he lived at number 9 from 1961–65 – and it is often visited by admirers of his work. The novelist and short-story writer [[Jean Rhys]] lived in Flat 22 in Paulton House in the square from 1936–38 and the winner of the 1969 [[Nobel Prize for Literature]], [[Samuel Beckett]], lived at number 48 Paulton Square from 1933–34. The winner of the 1948 [[Nobel Prize in Physics]] [[Patrick Blackett]], also lived at No. 48. Other residents include the painters [[Augustus John]] at No.45, and [[Paul Nash (artist)|Paul Nash]] at No.19, the poet [[Kathleen Raine]] at No.47, and lexicographer [[Henry Watson Fowler]], at No.14. Beckett, Blackett, Rhys, Fowler and Maxwell all have blue plaques.

The garden is {{convert|0.3535|ha|acre|abbr=off}} in size and was redesigned for the third millennium in 2000. It is not open to the public and accessible only by local residents.<ref name=LGO>{{cite web|url=http://www.londongardensonline.org.uk/gardens-online-record.asp?ID=KAC110|title=Paultons Square|publisher=London Gardens Online|accessdate=30 January 2016}}</ref>

'''Compossibility''' is a philosophical concept from [[Gottfried Wilhelm Leibniz]]. According to Leibniz, a complete individual thing (for example a person) is characterized by all its properties, and these determine its relations with other individuals. The existence of one individual may contradict the existence of another. A possible world is made up of individuals that are '''compossible'''—that is, individuals that can exist together. Leibniz indicates that a world is a set of compossible things, however, that a world is a kind of collection of things that God could bring into existence. For not even God can bring into existence a world in which there is some contradiction among its members or their properties.<ref>http://plato.stanford.edu/entries/leibniz-modal/</ref>

When Leibniz speaks of a possible world, he means a set of compossible, finite things that God could have brought into existence if he were not constrained by the goodness that is part of his nature. The actual world, on the other hand, is simply that set of finite things that is instantiated by God, because it is greatest in goodness, reality and perfection. Naturally, the fact that we are here experiencing this world—the actual world—means that there is at least one possible world. In Leibniz's view, there are an infinite number of possible worlds.<ref>{{cite journal |last=Brown |first=Gregory |year=1987 |title=Compossibility, Harmony, and Perfection in Leibniz |journal=The Philosophical Review |volume=96 |issue=2 |pages=173–203}}</ref>

According to the ''Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy'' entry on Leibniz's Modal Metaphysics by Brandon C. Look, views on \compossibility\" and the closely related [[best of all possible worlds]] argument are to be found  in ''On the Ultimate Origination of Things''
column5: ''The Discourse in Metaphysics''
column7: and throughout his works. The term itself is found in ''The Philosophical Writings III'' [''Die philosophischen Schriften III''] when Leibniz writes to [[Louis Bourguet]].<ref name=\"Leibniz's Modal Mechanics\">{{cite encyclopedia | url = http://plato.stanford.edu/entries/leibniz-modal/ | title = Leibniz's Modal Metaphysics | date = 2008-05-23 | accessdate = 2010-01-22 | encyclopedia = Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy | location = Palo Alto
